message.content:
An ATX (Advanced Technology eXtended) motherboard is a type of computer motherboard that conforms to the ATX standard established by the Association of Xtended Cabinet (AIC) in 1994. The ATX specification defines dimensions and features such as power connectors, mounting holes, and expansion slots for components like graphics cards and hard drives.

An ATX motherboard is designed to provide a consistent layout for hardware components, making it easier for users to upgrade their systems and improve compatibility between different manufacturers' parts. It has become the industry standard for desktop computers and includes features such as multiple power connectors (including one for the CPU), two or more PCI slots, and onboard audio and USB ports.

In addition to these features, ATX motherboards may also include additional expansion slots, SATA connections for storage devices, and various other features depending on their specifications and intended use cases.
